channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Judge Orders Blood Bags Destroyed in Puerto Doping Case
item.description: After a doctor was convicted for his role in doping cyclists, the Spanish judge ruled that blood bags gathered in 2006 from the doctor’s office could not be released to antidoping authorities.
item.dc:creator: By JULIET MACUR
item.media:description: Dr. Eufemiano Fuentes arriving at a criminal court in Madrid, Spain, in February.

item.title: Austerity Reaches France’s Presidential Wine Cellar
item.description: François Hollande, a Socialist who has made a point of trying to be a “normal president,” will auction off 1,200 bottles, buy more modest vintages and return the savings.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Friction Between U.S. and Mexico Threatens Efforts on Drugs
item.description: Political sensitivities over the United States’ involvement in Mexico are longstanding, but policy changes under the new president, Enrique Peña Nieto, have rattled American officials.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD, DAMIEN CAVE and GINGER THOMPSON
item.media:credit: Ginnette Riquelme Q for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the headquarters of a state-owned oil company, Pemex, a day after an explosion on Jan. 31, in which 37 people died and more than 120 were injured.

item.title: Obama's News Conference in 3 Minutes
item.description: The president answered questions Tuesday on topics ranging from the Boston bombing investigation to Syria to Jason Collins.

item.title: New Bombings in Syria as Obama Resists Bigger Role
item.description: On a day when twin bombings in Syria killed at least 18 people, President Obama strongly suggested that he would not be rushed into a military campaign.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A man injured in an explosion in central Damascus on Tuesday was carried from the scene.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 30
item.description: Indian security personnel inspect a defused bomb on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Indian security personnel inspecting the parts of a bomb, which they detected and defused, on the outskirts of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Obama to Seek Closing Amid Hunger Strike at Guantánamo
item.description: President Obama renewed his years-old vow to shutter the prison in Cuba on Tuesday after “medical reinforcements” were called in to help force-feed inmates protesting their detention without trial.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: India Ink: 4-Year-Old Rape Victim Dies in India
item.description: A 4-year-old girl who was raped and dumped near a crematorium in central India died on Monday evening from cardiac arrest, hospital authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA and MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: At War Blog: Humbled by the Souvenirs of War
item.description: For one Marine, the 10th anniversary of the invasion of Iraq brings back vivid memories, not all of them unwanted, of his first firefight.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW P. CLIFFORD
item.media:description: Andrew P. Clifford, pictured in Baghdad in 2003, was a machine-gunner with the Marines in Iraq.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 30
item.description: Wastewater worries in Fukushima; rampage in Nigeria; Cyprus faults the E.C.B; progress on AIDS; a new fashion district in Vienna; van Gogh’s colors; and a martial arts league.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Gray and silver storage tanks filled with radioactive wastewater are sprawling over the grounds of the Fukushima Daiichi plant.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Chinese Cruise to Disputed Paracel Islands Angers Vietnam
item.description: In a move China calls “tourism” but others have likened more to “imperialism”, a first Chinese cruise ship is currently touring the Paracel Islands, claimed by China, Vietnam and Taiwan, Chinese media reported.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from the Internet of a Liaoning Satellite TV report on the first Chinese cruise to the Paracel Islands, showing what appears to be Yongxing Island, Woody Island in English and Phu Lam Island in Vietnamese, with its landing strip.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Billions of Cellphones Polluting the World
item.description: As people in emerging economies adopt more mobile technology, global metal needs will be three to nine times larger than all the metals currently used in the world.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:description: Old mobile phones were on display at the CeBit trade fair in Hanover, Germany in March.

item.title: The Female Factor: The Face of the Gay Rights Movement
item.description: High-profile men have tightened their hold on the leadership as strategists, promoters, spokesmen and financiers.
item.dc:creator: By LUISITA LOPEZ TORREGROSA

item.title: Prosecutors Raid South Korean Spy Agency
item.description: The state is investigating allegations that the intelligence service tried to influence the recent presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Israeli Airstrike Kills Palestinian in Gaza
item.description: A Palestinian militant was killed in the strike hours after an Israeli citizen was stabbed to death by a Palestinian. The two attacks raised the specter of further confrontation.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: European Unemployment Sets Another Record
item.description: On the eve of the international Labor Day holiday, a new report served as a reminder that joblessness remains among Europe’s biggest problems.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: American Public Opposes Action in Syria and North Korea
item.description: Majorities across party lines say the economy dwarfs all other issues, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MEGAN THEE-BRENAN

item.title: Collapsed Building Owner's Property to Be Seized
item.description: A top Bangladesh court on Tuesday ordered the government to “immediately” confiscate the property of a collapsed building’s owner, as thousands of protesters clashed with police, leaving 100 people injured.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers escorted Mohammed Sohel Rana, owner of the building that collapsed in Bangladesh last week, into court on Monday.

item.title: Remaining South Korean Managers Leave Plant in North
item.description: Political tensions drove the two Koreas to sever their last economic ties, which had been through the Kaesong Industrial Complex.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Queen Beatrix Abdicates in the Netherlands
item.description: After a 33-year reign, Queen Beatrix handed over on Tuesday to her son, Willem-Alexander, the country’s first king in 123 years.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The Dutch Crown Prince Willem-Alexander with his mother, Queen Beatrix, during an abdication ceremony at the Royal Palace in Amsterdam on Tuesday.

item.title: It’s the Economy: Is It Crazy to Think We Can Eradicate Poverty?
item.description: The end to extreme poverty might very well be within reach. But is the bar too low?
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: International Schools Boom as More Seek Education in English
item.description: There are now 6,400 international schools all over the world, with new ones opening all the time. A job fair in London is a snapshot of Western teachers desperate for a job meeting up with institutions desperate to fill their ranks. Have you studied or taught at an international school? Tell us your experiences.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: Teachers lined up at an interview sign-up session at the Council of International Schools' recruitment fair in London.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Director Feroz Abbas Khan
item.description: The director of “Gandhi, My Father” on his new film, “Dekh Tamasha Dekh,” a satire about an unidentified dead man.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVANI VORA
item.media:credit: Courtesy of New York Indian Film Festival

item.title: India Ink: Guinness Record Holder Dies Performing Stunt Over Teesta River
item.description: Sailendra Nath Roy tried to cross a West Bengal river using his hair.
item.dc:creator: By SRUTHI GOTTIPATI
item.media:description: Sailendra Nath Roy, a Guinness World Record holder, attempting to cross the river Teesta on the outskirts of Siliguri in West Bengal on Sunday.

item.title: Afghan Leader Confirms Cash Deliveries by C.I.A.
item.description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan described the bags of cash dropped off at his office for a decade as a “small amount,” though he offered few other details.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Off-the-books cash delivered directly to President Karzai’s office shows payments on a vast scale.
